title: Berwickshire Coastal Path Walking Route

nearby.description: Coldingham Bay to St Abbs and Coldingham Loch Walk

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Cliffs from Berwickshire Coastal path, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cliffs from Berwickshire Coastal path

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Berwickshire Coastal Path at Marshall Meadows, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Berwickshire Coastal Path at Marshall Meadows Coastal path north of Berwick-upon-Tweed. At this point the path follows the line of the East Coast Rail line and the border between England and Scotland is 0.5 mile further on.

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Welcome to Scotland, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Welcome to Scotland Scottish side of the English/Scottish border on the Berwickshire Coastal Path.

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Ruin at Lamberton Skerrs, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ruin at Lamberton Skerrs North of Berwick-upon-Tweed and visible from the Berwickshire Coastal Path.

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Clifftops at Marshall Meadows Point, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clifftops at Marshall Meadows Point Remains of a clifftop wall along the Berwickshire Coastal Path.

images.title: Maureen Wright / Abbey Burn and Linkim Shore, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Abbey Burn and Linkim Shore. Looking towards Linkim Shore from the Berwickshire Coastal Path as it passes through valley of Abbey Burn. This is where the burn enters the sea.

images.title: Lisa Jarvis / Cowdrait, Burnmouth, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cowdrait, Burnmouth. The small communities of Cowdrait and Ross (the last 4 houses on the left hand side) as seen from the Berwickshire Coastal Path that descends into Cowdrait, through the back gardens. The headland is known as Ross Point.

images.title: James Allan / Creel Road, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Creel Road. A section of the Berwickshire Coastal Path between Coldingham and St Abb's.

description: Follow the Berwickshire Coastal Path from Berwick on Tweed in Northumberland, to Cockburnspath, in the Scottish Borders. There's some spectacular coastal scenery to enjoy as you pass along the Northumberland and Scottish cliff tops. There are also a series of pretty coastal villages with delightful harbours including Burnmouth, Eyemouth, St Abbs and Cove. The Berwick Walls Walk is a worthy walk to do at the start of the route. The short trail exposes you to the fascinating history of the town as you traverse the 16th century walls.
